cars.title: CARS Evaluation
cars.subtitle: Childhood Autism Rating Scale

descriptions.none: The child shows minimal behaviors characteristic of autism.
descriptions.mild_moderate: Behavioral patterns suggest mild-to-moderate symptoms of autism.
descriptions.severe: Clinical findings indicate severe symptoms of autism requiring high support.

cars.no_evaluations_desc: Start a CARS evaluation to identify and classify behavioral patterns related to autism.
cars.scoring_instruction: Each item is scored from 1 to 4. Use half-points (1.5, 2.5, 3.5) for behaviors that fall between categories. A detailed clinical note is highly recommended for any score above 1.
cars.observation_placeholder: Justify this score with specific clinical observations...

1.title: Relating to People
1.d1: No evidence of difficulty or abnormality in relating to people. The child's behavior is appropriate for his or her age. Some shyness, fussiness, or annoyance may be observed when being told what to do, but not to an unusual degree.
1.d2: Mildly abnormal relationships. The child may avoid looking the adult in the eye, avoid the adult or become fussy if interaction is forced, be excessively shy, not be as responsive to the adult as a typical child of the same age, or cling to parents somewhat more than most children of the same age.
1.d3: Moderately abnormal relationships. The child shows aloofness (is distant) at times (seems difficult to reach). Persistent attempts by the adult are required to get the child's attention. The child initiates minimal contact.
1.d4: Severely abnormal relationships. The child is consistently aloof or unaware of what the adult is doing. He or she almost never responds to or initiates contact with the adult. Only the most persistent attempts to get attention have any effect.

2.title: Imitation
2.d1: Appropriate imitation. The child can imitate sounds, words, and movements that are appropriate for his or her developmental level.
2.d2: Mildly abnormal imitation. The child imitates simple behaviors such as clapping or single verbal sounds most of the time; occasionally, imitates only after some persistence or after a delay.
2.d3: Moderately abnormal imitation. The child imitates only part of the time and require a great deal of persistence and help from the adult; frequently imitates only after a delay.
2.d4: Severely abnormal imitation. The child rarely or never imitates sounds, words, or movements even with persistence and help from the adult.

3.title: Emotional Response
3.d1: Age-appropriate and situation-appropriate emotional response. The child shows the appropriate type and degree of emotional response, as indicated by a change in facial expression, posture, and manner.
3.d2: Mildly abnormal emotional response. The child occasionally shows a somewhat inappropriate type or degree of emotional reaction. Reactions are sometimes unrelated to the objects or events surrounding them.
3.d3: Moderately abnormal emotional response. The child shows definite signs of inappropriate type and/or degree of emotional response. Reactions may be quite inhibited or excessive and unrelated to the situation; may grimace, laugh, or become rigid even though no emotion-producing objects or events are present.
3.d4: Severely abnormal emotional response. Responses are seldom appropriate to the situation; once the child gets into a certain mood, it is very difficult to change. Conversely, the child may show wildly different emotions when nothing has changed.

4.title: Body Use
4.d1: Age-appropriate body use. The child moves with the same ease, agility, and coordination as a typical child of the same age.
4.d2: Mildly abnormal body use. Some minor peculiarities, such as clumsiness, repetitive movements, poor coordination, or the rare appearance of unusual movements, may be present.
4.d3: Moderately abnormal body use. Behaviors that are clearly strange or unusual for a child of this age may include strange finger movements, peculiar body or finger postures, staring at or picking at the body, self-aggression, rocking, spinning, or toe-walking.
4.d4: Severely abnormal body use. Intense or frequent movements of the type listed above are signs of severely abnormal body use. These behaviors may persist despite attempts to discourage the child or involve the child in other activities.

5.title: Object Use
5.d1: Appropriate interest in and use of toys and other objects. The child shows a normal interest in toys and other objects appropriate for his or her developmental level and uses them appropriately.
5.d2: Mildly abnormal interest in or use of toys and other objects. The child may show an atypical interest in a toy or play with it in an immature way (e.g., banging the toy or sucking on it).
5.d3: Moderately abnormal interest in or use of toys and other objects. The child may show little interest in toys or other objects, or may be preoccupied with using them in a strange way. He or she may focus on some insignificant part of a toy, become fascinated with light reflecting off the object, repetitively move some part of the object, or play exclusively with one object.
5.d4: Severely abnormal interest in or use of toys and other objects. The child may engage in the same behaviors as above, but with greater frequency and intensity. It is difficult to distract the child when engaged in these inappropriate activities.

6.title: Adaptation to Change
6.d1: Age-appropriate response to change. While noting or commenting on changes in routine, the child accepts the changes without undue distress.
6.d2: Mildly abnormal adaptation to change. When an adult tries to change tasks, the child may continue the same activity or use the same materials.
6.d3: Moderately abnormal adaptation to change. The child actively resists changes in routine, tries to continue the old activity, and is difficult to distract. He or she may become unhappy and unhappy when an established routine is altered.
6.d4: Severely abnormal adaptation to change. The child shows severe reactions to change. If a change is forced, he or she may become extremely angry or uncooperative and may have a tantrum.

7.title: Visual Response
7.d1: Age-appropriate visual response. The child's visual behavior is normal and appropriate for his or her age. Vision is used together with other senses as a way to explore a new object.
7.d2: Mildly abnormal visual response. The child must occasionally be reminded to look at objects. The child may be more interested in looking at mirrors or lights than at his or her peers, may occasionally stare into space, or may avoid eye contact.
7.d3: Moderately abnormal visual response. The child must be reminded frequently to look at what he or she is doing. He or she may stare into space, avoid looking people in the eye, look at objects from an unusual angle, or hold objects very close to the eyes.
7.d4: Severely abnormal visual response. The child consistently avoids eye contact, stares fixedly at objects, holds objects close to the face, or looks at them peripherally. Extremely strange visual behavior is present.

8.title: Listening Response
8.d1: Age-appropriate listening response. The child's listening behavior is normal and appropriate for his or her age. Hearing is used together with other senses.
8.d2: Mildly abnormal listening response. There may be some lack of response or mild over-reaction to certain sounds. Reactions may be delayed, and sounds may require repetition to get the child's attention. The child may be distracted by external sounds.
8.d3: Moderately abnormal listening response. The child's responses to sounds vary; often ignores a sound the first few times it is made, may be startled or may cover ears when hearing some everyday sounds.
8.d4: Severely abnormal listening response. The child over-reacts and/or under-reacts to sounds to an extreme degree, regardless of the type of sound.

9.title: Taste, Smell, and Touch Response and Use
9.d1: Normal use of and response to taste, smell, and touch. The child explores new objects in an age-appropriate manner, generally by feeling and looking at them. Taste or smell may be used when appropriate. When reacting to minor everyday pain, the child expresses discomfort but does not over-react.
9.d2: Mildly abnormal use and response. The child may persist in putting objects in his or her mouth; may smell or taste inedible objects. May ignore or over-react to mild pain, which a typical child would express only as discomfort.
9.d3: Moderately abnormal use and response. The child may be moderately preoccupied with touching, smelling, or tasting objects or people. The child may react either too much or too little.
9.d4: Severely abnormal use and response. The child is preoccupied with smelling, tasting, or feeling objects more for the sensation than for normal exploration or use of the object. The child may completely ignore pain or react very strongly to a mild discomfort.

10.title: Fear or Nervousness
10.d1: Normal fear or nervousness. The child's behavior is appropriate both to the situation and to his or her age.
10.d2: Mildly abnormal fear or nervousness. The child occasionally shows either too much or too little fear or nervousness compared to the reaction of a typical child of the same age in a similar situation.
10.d3: Moderately abnormal fear or nervousness. The child shows either quite a bit more or quite a bit less fear than is typical even for a younger child in a similar situation.
10.d4: Severely abnormal fear or nervousness. Fear persists even after repeated experience with harmless events or objects. It is extremely difficult to calm or comfort the child. The child may, conversely, show no regard for dangers that other children of the same age avoid.

11.title: Verbal Communication
11.d1: Normal verbal communication, age-appropriate and situation-appropriate.
11.d2: Mildly abnormal verbal communication. Speech shows an overall delay. Most of the speech makes sense; however, echolalia or pronoun reversal may occur occasionally. Some peculiar words or jargon may be used occasionally.
11.d3: Moderately abnormal verbal communication. Speech may be absent. When present, verbal communication may be a mix of some meaningful speech and peculiar speech such as jargon, echolalia, or pronoun reversal. Peculiarities in meaningful speech include excessive questioning or preoccupation with particular topics.
11.d4: Severely abnormal verbal communication. Meaningful speech is not used. The child may make infantile screams, strange or animal-like sounds, complex noises resembling speech, or may show persistent and bizarre use of some recognizable words or phrases.

12.title: Nonverbal Communication
12.d1: Normal use of nonverbal communication, age-appropriate and situation-appropriate.
12.d2: Mildly abnormal use of nonverbal communication. Immature use of nonverbal communication; may point vaguely or reach for what he or she wants, in situations where a child of the same age would point or gesture more specifically to indicate what he or she wants.
12.d3: Moderately abnormal nonverbal communication. The child is generally unable to express needs or desires nonverbally, and cannot understand the nonverbal communication of others.
12.d4: Severely abnormal nonverbal communication. The child uses only bizarre or peculiar gestures that have no apparent meaning, and shows no awareness of the meanings associated with the gestures or facial expressions of others.

13.title: Activity Level
13.d1: Normal activity level for age and circumstances. The child is neither more active nor less active than a typical child of the same age in a similar situation.
13.d2: Mildly abnormal activity level. The child may be either slightly restless or somewhat 'sluggish' and moves slowly at times. The child's activity level interferes only slightly with his or her performance.
13.d3: Moderately abnormal activity level. The child may be quite active and difficult to restrain. He or she may have boundless energy and may not go to bed easily at night. Conversely, the child may be quite lethargic and require a great deal of prodding to get moving.
13.d4: Severely abnormal activity level. The child exhibits extremes of activity or inactivity and may even shift from one extreme to the other.

14.title: Level and Consistency of Intellectual Response
14.d1: Intelligence is normal and consistent across various areas. The child is as smart as a typical child of his or her age and has no unusual intellectual abilities or problems.
14.d2: Mildly abnormal intellectual functioning. The child is not as smart as a typical child of his or her age; skills appear fairly retarded across all areas.
14.d3: Moderately abnormal intellectual functioning. In general, the child is not as smart as a typical child of his or her age; however, the child may function nearly normally in one or more intellectual areas.
14.d4: Severely abnormal intellectual functioning. Even though the child is generally not as smart as a typical child of his or her age, he or she may function even better than a typical child of the same age in one or more areas.

15.title: General Impressions
15.d1: No autism. The child shows none of the symptoms characteristic of autism.
15.d2: Mild autism. The child shows only a few symptoms or only a mild degree of autism.
15.d3: Moderate autism. The child shows a number of symptoms or a moderate degree of autism.
15.d4: Severe autism. The child shows many symptoms or an extreme degree of autism.

help.title: Help & Documentation
help.subtitle: Everything you need to know about using TempoApp

dashboard.title: Dashboard & Overview
dashboard.description: Your clinical control center. The dashboard provides a high-level view of your daily operations, urgent tasks, and recent system updates.

widgets.title: Quick Stats Widgets
widgets.content: Located at the top of the dashboard, these cards show real-time metrics: Active Clients (total non-archived roster), Attendance Rate (percentage of completed vs. cancelled sessions for the current month), and Sessions Today (count of scheduled events for the current date). Clicking these widgets often leads to the detailed related section.

schedule.title: Today's Schedule
schedule.content: A vertical timeline of your sessions. You can quickly log attendance (Present, Absent, Excused) directly from the dashboard card. Clicking a session opens the full detail panel where you can record clinical notes and program scores. This view is filtered to show your own sessions if you are a Therapist, or the whole clinic if you are an Admin.

activity.title: Recent Activity Feed
activity.content: Displays a chronological list of system-wide events, such as new clients being registered, attendance being logged, or progress reports being generated. This helps the entire team stay updated on clinical changes without manual status meetings.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:
â€¢ Therapist Flow: Start your day by checking 'Today's Schedule' to see your assigned clients. After each session, use the quick actions to mark attendance and click 'Notes' to record the results of the intervention.
â€¢ Admin Flow: Check the 'Attendance Rate' widget to identify cancellation patterns across the clinic. Review 'Recent Activity' to monitor documentation compliance by the staff.

calendar.title: Calendar Management
calendar.description: Efficiently schedule and manage therapy sessions for your entire team. The calendar is the heart of TempoApp's coordination logic.

views.title: Calendar Views
views.content: Switch between Month, Week, and Day views. The Week view is optimized for mobile with a 3-day toggle to maximize vertical space. The Month view features an 'Agenda' mode on small screens, listing daily events in a scrollable list rather than a dense grid.

scheduling.title: Scheduling Sessions
scheduling.content: Click the 'New Event' button or any time slot. Choose between 'Therapy' (standard billing) or 'Evaluation' (standard protocols). You must assign at least one therapist and one client. The system automatically fetches the client's current intervention plan to pre-select active programs for the session.

recurring.title: Recurring Events
recurring.content: For long-term therapy, set up sessions that repeat weekly. You can specify an end date or leave it open. The system will handle overlaps and alert you if there are therapist schedule conflicts.

filtering.title: Advanced Filtering
filtering.content: Coordinators can filter the entire clinic view by Therapist to check for availability or by Client to see their specific therapy dosage. Filters persist during your session for easier navigation.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:
â€¢ Coordinator Flow: Open 'Week View', filter by 'Therapist A' and 'Therapist B' to find a matching gap for a sibling group session. Click the slot, add both clients, and save as a 'Recurring' session.
â€¢ Therapist Flow: Use the 'Day View' on your mobile device to see specific room assignments and client notes before the session begins.

clients.title: Client Management
clients.description: Manage the full clinical lifecycle of your patients. From initial intake and diagnosis to standardized testing and graduation.

profiles.title: Centralized Profiles
profiles.content: Each client profile is a single source of truth. You can view personal details (birth date, diagnosis, support level), contact information for parents, and the assigned clinical team. The profile uses a tabbed interface to separate medical history from current progress.

evaluations.title: Running Assessments
evaluations.content: Perform VB-MAPP, ABLLS-R, CARS, Portage, or Carolina assessments. The system guides you through the protocol, allowing you to save drafts. Once 'Completed', the results generate a radar chart comparing current skills against previous assessments to highlight developmental growth.

plans.title: Digital IEPs & Plans
plans.content: Intervention plans allow you to link specific programs (e.g., 'Eye Contact', 'Mand Requesting') to a client. Therapists can then record trial results (Success/Prompted/Incorrect) during sessions, which automatically updates the client's progress charts.

homework.title: Parent Engagement
homework.content: Extend therapy beyond the clinic by assigning 'Homework'. Therapists can write instructions for home practice. Parents access these from their own portal, where they can mark tasks as 'Done' and provide feedback on the child's performance at home.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:
â€¢ Therapist Flow: Open a client's profile, go to the 'Evaluations' tab, and start a new 'VB-MAPP'. Score the milestones observed during the week. Once finished, click 'View Report' to see the automatically generated developmental age analysis.
â€¢ Admin Flow: Review the 'Docs' tab of a client to ensure all consent forms and medical certificates are uploaded and valid.

team.title: Team & Permissions
team.description: Control system access, manage staff records, and monitor professional performance.

rbac.title: Access Control (RBAC)
rbac.content: Security is handled via roles. 'Superadmin' has full access including database rules. 'Admin' manages billing and clinic-wide settings. 'Coordinator' handles scheduling and team assignments. 'Therapist' focuses on client clinical data. You can change a member's role at any time from the Team Member modal.

reports.title: Professional KPI Reports
reports.content: Monitor staff performance by generating PDF reports. These include total session hours, number of active clients, and a breakdown of service types provided. This is essential for calculating bonuses or conducting performance reviews.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:
â€¢ Superadmin Flow: When a new staff member joins, go to 'Team', click 'Add Member', enter their email, and assign them the 'Coordinator' role. The user will then receive an invitation to set up their account.
â€¢ Admin Flow: At the end of the month, open a Therapist's card and click 'Generate Report' to see their total billable hours for payroll processing.

billing.title: Billing & Financials
billing.description: Integrated billing system designed for clinical operations. Automate invoicing and track clinic overheads.

multi_entity.title: Multi-Legal Entity
multi_entity.content: Configure multiple clinics or legal entities within the same account. When generating invoices, select the issuing entity to apply the correct header, series, and bank details. This is ideal for organizations operating under different registered names.

smartbill.title: SmartBill Synchronization
smartbill.content: Link your SmartBill account to automatically sync generated invoices. This ensures your official accounting is always up-to-date without manual data entry. The system will alert you if a sync fails.

expenses.title: Expense Tracking
expenses.content: Log clinic overheads such as rent, utilities, and supplies. Categorize expenses and set them as recurring to automatically project your monthly profit. View expense charts in the Analytics section.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:
â€¢ Admin Flow: At the end of the month, go to 'Billing', click 'Generate Invoices'. Review the sessions for 'Client X', select 'Clinic Entity A', and click 'Sync to SmartBill'. The parent will automatically receive the invoice via email.
â€¢ Superadmin Flow: Go to 'Settings' > 'Billing Config' to add a second legal entity with its own IBAN and VAT rate.

analytics.title: Analytics & Insights
analytics.description: Data-driven decisions for your clinic. Monitor clinical efficacy and financial health through interactive visualizations.

progress.title: Clinical Progress Index
progress.content: Monitor the global goal achievement rate across all active intervention plans. This metric aggregate's every trial recorded in the clinic to show you how effective your programs are.

revenue.title: Revenue Mix
revenue.content: Analyze which service types (e.g., 'Speech Therapy' vs 'ABA') are generating the most value. View monthly revenue trends and projected income based on scheduled sessions.

utilization.title: Therapist Utilization
utilization.content: Monitor therapist workload and capacity. The system compares scheduled hours against the therapist's target capacity to identify who is over-capacity or has room for more clients.

user_flow.title: Example Workflow
user_flow.content:

settings.title: System Configuration
settings.description: Customize TempoApp to fit your clinic's specific needs. Manage preferences and system-wide constraints.

notifications.title: Notification Preferences
notifications.content: Configure which system events trigger in-app alerts or email notifications. Each team member can customize their own preferences to avoid 'notification fatigue'.

limits.title: Account Limits
limits.content: Admins can set maximum caps for active clients and team members based on their subscription level. The system will prevent adding new clients if the limit is reached.
